Evidence: Pandemic disruptions exacerbated inequities for rural, Indigenous, newcomer, and low-income youth.
Growing Up Strong’s 'hub-and-spoke' provincial model aligns with emerging best practices for reaching dispersed communities.
A 2024 study found a 4-week Indigenous dance program bolstered adolescents’ mental health and wellness.
Indigenous youth reported dance 'helps me escape… makes me feel good… and is really fun.'
Youth expressed 'I can be myself'—indicating confidence and identity strengthening.
Study showed dance participation led to better school attendance.
Powwow dancing helps Indigenous people heal intergenerational trauma and build supportive 'powwow families.'
COVID-19 worsened mental health disparities and cultural disconnection among Indigenous youth.
Immigrant youth face higher susceptibility to poor mental and overall health due to poverty, trauma, and acculturation stress.
93% of newcomer families chose informal activities (walking, swimming) vs. formal sport.
Newcomer barriers include unfamiliarity with systems, limited time, and income—not lack of interest.
Culturally responsive programs reduce isolation and help newcomer kids build friendships and language skills.
Canada has embedded sport/arts into national integration strategies since the 1990s.
Rural youth experienced higher mental health hospitalization rates during COVID-19.
Hub-and-spoke delivery serves more rural communities with fewer resources.
Rural youth face limited recreation options and social isolation.
Programs like dance residencies are 'vital' interventions for rural youth well-being.
Literature calls for equity-focused investments so marginalized youth can participate fully.
Cost, transportation, and discrimination remain core barriers for marginalized youth.
Arts access is now recognized as a social determinant of health.
Subsidized cultural programming improved youth coping skills, cultural pride, and confidence.
Reaching vulnerable youth may involve health and social services working with arts organizations.
Growing Up Strong’s mandate—reducing barriers and targeting underserved youth—aligns closely with post-pandemic recommendations.
